facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 771 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 771 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated H May 29, 1964, of the Mysore High Court in Civil Petition No. 90 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 29, 1964 of Mysore High Court in Civil Petition No. 90 of 1964

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated H May 29, 1964, of the Mysore High Court in Civil Petition No. 90 of 1964. S. Khanduja and Ganpat Rai, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah J. On May 5, 1964 the respondents-hereinafter called the plaintiffs-instituted in the High Court of Mysore an action in the nature of a passing off action against the appellants-hereinafter called the defendants--for a declaration that they are exclusive owners of the trade mark companysisting of the letters R.S.F. and No. 806, for a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from passing off their washing soap as the goods of the plaintiffs and for incidental reliefs.

facts.text: On May 5, 1964 plaintiffs instituted passing off action in High Court of Mysore against defendants

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated H May 29, 1964, of the Mysore High Court in Civil Petition No. 90 of 1964. S. Khanduja and Ganpat Rai, for the appellants.

By s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 43 of 1958 a passing off action whether the trade mark is registered or unregistered may be instituted in any court number inferior to a District Court having jurisdiction to try the suit. Among the powers companyferred upon a High Court by s. 24 Code of Civil Procedure, there is enumerated the power to withdraw any suit, appeal or other proceeding in any Court subordinate to it, and to try or dispose of the same S. 24 1   b   i . But jurisdiction to try a suit, appeal or proceeding by a High Court under the power reserved by s. 24 1   b   i  arises only if the suit, appeal or proceeding is properly instituted in a companyrt subordinate to the High Court, and the suit, appeal or proceeding is in exercise of the power of the High Court transferred to it.

arguments.claim: Mysore High Court jurisdiction governed by Mysore Act 5 of 1962, which is regulatory and confers no original or appellate jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Exercise of jurisdiction by the High Court of Mysore is governed by Mysore Act 5 of 1962. The Act is purely a regulatory Act enacted for regulating the business and exercise of the powers of the High Court in relation to the administration of justice it does not purport to confer upon the High Court any jurisdiction original or appellate.

arguments.claim: Section 12 Mysore HC Act 1884 authorised investment of ordinary original jurisdiction but repealed by s.14 Mysore Act 5/1962

anchor.surface_text: by s. 12 of the Mysore High Court Act 1 of 1884 enacted by the Maharaja of Mysore to amend the constitution of the High Court of Mysore, and to provide for the administration of justice by that Court, the Government of Mysore was authorised by notification to invest the High Court with ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court... But s. 12 of the Mysore Act 1 of 1884 has been repealed by s. 14 of Mysore Act 5 of 1962.

arguments.claim: Mysore High Court primarily appellate, exercises original jurisdiction only where specifically invested by special Acts

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore is by its constitution primarily a court exercising appellate jurisdiction it is competent to exercise original jurisdiction only in those matters in respect of which by special Acts it has been specifically invested with jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Mysore High Court not invested with ordinary original civil jurisdiction of District Court, hence incompetent under s.105 TMM Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is competent to exercise original jurisdiction under s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 43 of 1958 if it is invested with the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court, and not otherwise, and the High Court of Mysore not being invested by any statute or under its constitution with that jurisdiction was incompetent to entertain a passing off action.

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction is extent of authority prescribed by subject-matter, pecuniary value, local limits; cannot be enlarged absent express conferment

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of a Court means the extent of the authority of a Court to administer justice prescribed with reference to the subject-matter, pecuniary value and local limits. Barring cases in which jurisdiction is expressly conferred upon it by special statutes, e.g. the Companies Act the Banking Companies Act, the High Court of Mysore exercises appellate jurisdiction alone.

arguments.claim: s.24(1)(b)(i) CPC power to withdraw and try arises only if proceeding properly instituted in subordinate court and transferred

anchor.surface_text: Section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure... power to withdraw any suit, appeal or other proceeding in any Court subordinate to it, and to try or dispose of the same S. 24 1   b   i . But jurisdiction to try a suit... arises only if the suit... is properly instituted in a court subordinate to the High Court, and the suit... is in exercise of the power of the High Court transferred to it.

arguments.claim: s.151 CPC inherent powers exercisable only where proceeding lawfully before court, does not confer jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure preserves the in- herent power of the Court as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court. That power may be exercised where there is a proceeding lawfully before the High Court it does not however authorise the High Court to invest itself with jurisdiction where it is not conferred by law.

arguments.claim: Extraordinary situation like court vacation does not enlarge jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: By jurisdiction is meant the extent of the power Which is conferred upon the Court by its constitution to try a proceeding its exercise cannot be enlarged because what the learned Judge calls an extraordinary situation requires the Court to exercise it.

holdings.text: The High Court of Mysore not being invested by any statute or under its constitution with the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court was incompetent to entertain a passing off action under s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is competent to exercise original jurisdiction under s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 43 of 1958 if it is invested with the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court, and not otherwise, and the High Court of Mysore not being invested by any statute or under its constitution with that jurisdiction was incompetent to entertain a passing off action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.105 TMM Act requiring institution in court not inferior to District Court; defines District Court per s.2(e) TMM and s.2(4) CPC to include High Courts with ordinary original civil jurisdiction; Mysore HC lacks such jurisdiction as primarily appellate and s.12 of 1884 Act repealed without replacement

holdings.text: A High Court possessed of ordinary original civil jurisdiction is included in the expression 'District Court' for purposes of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act, 1958 when exercising that jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 4  of the Code defines a district as meaning the local limits of the jurisdiction of a principal civil court- called the District Court-and includes the local limits of the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a High Court. If therefore a High Court is possessed of ordinary original civil jurisdiction, it would, when exercising that jurisdiction be included, for the purpose of Act 43 of 1958, in the expression District Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation linking s.2(e) TMM Act to s.2(4) CPC definition of district encompassing High Courts' ordinary original civil jurisdiction

holdings.text: High Court of Mysore exercises appellate jurisdiction alone barring cases expressly conferred by special statutes and lacks ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is competent to exercise original jurisdiction under s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 43 of 1958 if it is invested with the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court, and not otherwise, and the High Court of Mysore not being invested by any statute or under its constitution with that jurisdiction was incompetent to entertain a passing off action.
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.

edges.explanation: Holding on inclusion of High Courts with ordinary original jurisdiction addresses the issue of Mysore High Court's equivalence to District Court

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 4  of the Code defines a district as meaning the local limits of the jurisdiction of a principal civil court- called the District Court-and includes the local limits of the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a High Court. If therefore a High Court is possessed of ordinary original civil jurisdiction, it would, when exercising that jurisdiction be included, for the purpose of Act 43 of 1958, in the expression District Court.
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore is by its constitution primarily a court exercising appellate jurisdiction it is competent to exercise original jurisdiction only in those matters in respect of which by special Acts it has been specifically invested with jurisdiction. The High Court is competent to exercise original jurisdiction under s. 105 of the Trade and Merchandise Marks Act 43 of 1958 if it is invested with the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of a District Court, and not otherwise,
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.

Section 24 of the Code of Civil Procedure on which counsel for the plaintiffs relied lends no assistance to his argument. Among the powers conferred upon a High Court by s. 24 Code of Civil Procedure, there is enumerated the power to withdraw any suit, appeal or other proceeding in any Court subordinate to it, and to try or dispose of the same S. 24 1   b   i . But jurisdiction to try a suit, appeal or proceeding by a High Court under the power reserved by s. 24 1   b   i  arises only if the suit,
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure preserves the in- herent power of the Court as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court. That power may be exercised where there is a proceeding lawfully before the High Court it does not however authorise the High Court to invest itself with jurisdiction where it is not conferred by law.
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.

anchor.surface_text: By jurisdiction is meant the extent of the power Which is conferred upon the Court by its constitution to try a proceeding its exercise cannot be enlarged because what the learned Judge calls an extraordinary situation requires the Court to exercise it.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction of a Court means the extent of the authority of a Court to administer justice prescribed with reference to the subject-matter, pecuniary value and local limits. Barring cases in which jurisdiction is expressly conferred upon it by special statutes, e.g. the Companies Act the Banking Companies Act, the High Court of Mysore exercises appellate jurisdiction alone.
The appeal must therefore be allowed. Temporary injunction granted by the High Court is vacated and the plaint is ordered to be returned for presentation to the proper Court.
